section.title: Requirements
section.p: Before beginning the installation, first confirm that you have met the following requirements.

ul.li:
Vim 7.x.x.
Minimum Vim Settings: In order for eclim to function properly, there is a minimum set of vim options that must be enabled in your vimrc file (:h vimrc).
set nocompatible
Execute :h 'compatible' for more info. You can confirm that compatibliity is turned off by executing the following:
:echo &compatible
Which should output '0'.
filetype plugin on
Execute :h filetype-plugin-on for more info. You can confirm that file type plugins are enabled by executing the following:
:filetype
Which should output 'filetype detection:ON plugin:ON indent:ON', showing at least 'ON' for 'detection' and 'plugin'.

section.title: Eclim Graphical Installer
section.p: Using the eclim graphical installer is the quickest and easiest way to install eclim on your system.

section.title: Step 1: Download the eclim installer for your platform.
Step 2: Run the installer.

ul.li:
Linux (and other unix based systems): You can start the installer by running the script you downloaded (note: you may have to make it executable first).
$ chmod 755 eclim_version.sh $ ./eclim_version.sh
Windows: On Windows systems, simply double click the eclim_version.exe file you downloaded.

section.p: After the installer starts up, simply follow the steps in the wizard to install the application.

section.title: Step 3: Start the eclimd server and test it.
Manual Installation
section.p: If for some reason you cannot use the graphical installer, these steps will walk you through how to perform a manual installation.

ol.li:
The first file you will need to download is the platform independent Vim plugins jar file:
eclim_vim_version.jar

The second file you will need to download is the platform dependent Eclipse plugins archive:
*nix:
org.eclim_version.tar.gz
Windows:
org.eclim_version.zip

section.title: Step 2: Install eclim Eclipse plugins.
section.p: Simply open a shell and extract the eclim Eclipse plugins archive to your Eclipse plugins directory.
Once you have the plug-in installed, before you can run the server, you must set the environment variable ECLIPSE_HOME to the location of your Eclipse installation.

ul.li: *nix: add export ECLIPSE_HOME="/usr/local/eclipse" to your .bashrc or equivelent for your prefered shell.
Windows: Start > Setting > Control Panel > System > Advanced (tab) > Environment Variables. From there add a new System or User variable for ECLIPSE_HOME.

section.title: Step 3: Install eclim Vim plugins.
section.p: Simply open a shell and extract the eclim Vim plugins jar file to one of the directories in your Vim runtime path.
section.note:
The directory to extract to depends on your platform, but you can find the appropriate directory by opening a Vim instance and executing:
:echo &rtp
This will echo a comma seperated list of directories in Vim's runtime path.
On *nix platforms, you would typically be extracting to the .vim directory in your home folder.
~/.vim
On Windows platforms, you would typically be extracting to the vimfiles directory in your C:\Documents and Settings\Username\ folder.
C:\Documents and Settings\Username\vimfiles
In some cases you might instead need to extract to vimfiles on your C drive.
C:\vimfiles

ul.li: Windows Users: On windows there are no additional installation steps for nailgun.

All Other Platforms: For all other platforms you will need 'gcc' and 'make' to compile nailgun for your system.
To do so, open a command prompt and change directories to ECLIPSE_HOME/plugins/org.eclim_version/src/nailgun. In that directory issue the command 'make'. After that finishes you should have an executable named 'ng' in the same directory. Simply copy or move that file to ECLIPSE_HOME/plugins/org.eclim_version/bin and you're all done.
$ cd $ECLIPSE_HOME/plugins/org.eclim_1.2.0/src/nailgun $ make $ mv ng ../../bin/

section.title: Step 5: Start the eclimd server and test it.
Starting and testing eclim.
section.p: Once you have finished the installation process, you can then start up the eclim server and verify that it is running properly.

ol.li: The first step is to start the eclimd server. To do so follow the directions found here.

Once you have started the server you can test it by opening a Vim window and issuing the command,
:PingEclim . The result of executing this command should be "eclim version" echoed to the bottom of your Vim window. If however, you receive "unable to connect to eclimd - connect: Connection refused", or something similar, then your eclimd server is not running or something is preventing eclim from connecting to it. If you receive this or any other errors and are unsure of what steps to take, please feel free to visit the forums so that someone can help resolve your issue.

section.title: What's Next
section.p: Now that you have eclim installed, the next step is to familiarize yourself with at least the core set of commands that eclim provides, all of which are found at the index of the eclim documentation.

section.title: Installer
section.p: When using the installer, the upgrading procedure is the same as the installation procedure. The installer will remove the previous version of eclim and install the new one.

section.title: Manual Upgrade
section.p: If you cannot use the installer, then you should follow these steps to ensure a smooth upgrade.

ol.li:
First check all the release notes from your currently installed version to the latest version, to see if there are any special upgrade notes that may apply to you.
These special upgrade notes will be in red warning boxes like this one so that they are easy to identify.
Delete the old org.eclim*_version plugins from your ECLIPSE_HOME/plugins directory.

Extract the new org.eclim_version.tar.gz
(or org.eclim_version.zip if on windows) to your ECLIPSE_HOME/plugins directory.

Extract your new eclim_vim_version.jar
file to your Vim runtimepath.
If you are on a non Windows system be sure to recompile the nailgun client.
